Topic.Title: Should you worry about earnings ?

Message.Msg: No, earnings don't matter. Earnings are at best an imaginary number, created to provide a more accurate picture of a company's financial activity than cash flow alone. But, investors and analysts focus on earnings, which is where they go wrong. What's important is cash flow.
Even if earnings are less than .09 / share, the stock won't drop much. If they blow away earnings, say 12 cents or so, look for a $15 bounce. What a stock! What a country!

Topic.Title: Should you worry about earnings ?

Message.Msg: So look at true DISCRETIONARY FCF, rather than encumbered increases in working capital with a negative float model... Amazon's net cash has collapsed over the past few years. TD FCF is pathetic. Operating cash flows have only grown from 3.5B to 4.18B (20%) from 2010 to 2012. Nice cash flow multiple expansion! This is a trasing scam and nothing more. Amazon has more tail risk exposure than any mega cap company. Someday Bethany McLean will be writing about this scam...

Topic.Title: Should you worry about earnings ?

Message.Msg: It does when Amazon suddenly finds a sharp drop in demand due to a shock that lasts longer than 90 days (current days payable) and reverse the working capital float. Cash drops hard in Q1 because the seasonal float from Q4 reverses anyway. If not for the $3B note in Q4, Amazon would have been in a rather uncomfortable position. I'm still amazed that the offering document had nothing on cash position and net working capital at the timing of the offering (but not so much at all the iBank upgrades that followed, particularly from those that did the offering...). Cash position and cash flow matter. Amazon has cavalierly levered up (off balance sheet liabilities, distribution/warehousing that haven't solved the last mile problem, etc). It's cost structure simply isn't what the analysts pretend. Look at GROSS shipping cost as a percent of net sales in the upcoming release. Amazon raised prices for FBA, so net will gain somewhat, but it still cannot solve the fundamental economic tradeoff which continues to move against Amazon. Oh, and Amazon's been releasing all the teasers it can to pump before earnings (Set top box, Ad network, etc). None of it will help solve the cash crunch that will be coming. For those that think Amazon isn't levered, its debt to book is already on par with industry norms.... (and that doesn't include its financial engineering...).

Topic.Title: Should you worry about earnings ?

Message.Msg: wuwu: Logic says: Two negatives multiplied become positive. The question that then pops-up here is simply this: Since this phenomenon is so well known by now in the last 18-quarters that its obvious to everyone. And when something becomes so obvious, it becomes ineffective in the street as an input-variable, to plan your game on. So, does that mean then: "This time its different" ... and any one willing to initiate massive new short positions tomorrow then? (other than perpetually maintained small, routine ones). Thats a billion-dollar question.

Topic.Title: Earnings (again)

Message.Msg: Jeff has been feeding the analysts the new margin growth story so they can totally reinvent mathemagical models to hockeystick in the future, since the past promises are failing to deliver. It will be just like last quarter where some analysts reduced out year revenues by 20-30% but still kept the price target and buy recommendation. I had an interesting conversation with Bethany McLean a few weeks back. She makes the point in her new book that everyone enables this kind of BS (optimism biases, etc). I pointed out that there is a difference between sophisticated players armed with aymmetric information (think of HFT as having radar to understand the shape of demand where others have at best line of sight in foggy conditions) and then exploiting cognitive biases and behavioral investing against John Q. Public. Likewise, the analysts and financial media are presumably more sophisticated and culpable in perpetrating these trading scams. In the case of Enron, it was company fraud. In the case of Amazon, it is the willful negligence of the analysts community and the financial media that will raise the ire of the public in retrospect...
